attributes.title: Speed and force of simple motor reaction as the indicators of the analgesic placebo effect
attributes.description: The correlation of the endogenous opioid relief or cannabinoid receptor activation and the appearance of the analgesic placebo effect is considered an important confirmation of the existence of the biological basis of the placebo effect. Such findings suggest that the analgesic placebo effect is a real physiological phenomenon since those physiological changes are most commonly connected to subjective pain estimates as a fundamental indicator of a placebo effect. The aim of this study was to test the effect of a placebo treatment to a) subjective estimates of the severity of a pain stimulation; b) objective measures of pain stimulate. However, studies showed that both the speed and the force of a simple motor reaction are correlated to the severity of the pain sensation. Thus the study aimed to test if the placebo treatment if it appeared at the level of subjective assessments, will be accompanied on both of those objective measures of the sensation. The existence of that kind of correlation can contribute to setting important guidelines in the understanding of the mechanism of the analgesic placebo effect.

q1.value: Nikolina Šaravanja, Dragutin Ivanec, Damir Lučanin

q2.value:
It is reasonable to expect that characteristics of a simple motor response could be an objective indicator of a change in the intensity of sensations which can be caused by a pain simulation in the presence of a placebo treatment compared to a controlled situation without such treatment. Such objective measures of the sensor intensity could additionally enlighten possible mechanisms of the analgesic placebo effect. If placebo treatment results in changes in early phases of nociception or early modulation of the intensity of pain sensation, the following is expected:
H1) Effects of the placebo manipulation would be present not only on subjective measures but on speed and the force of a reaction to a pain simulation.
H2) The differential placebo effect would be present on all measures of the placebo effect in experimental groups where the likelihood and the intensity of the placebo effect were manipulated in a different way. A greater effect would be present in a group in which the placebo treatment was based on both the conditioning and the formation of expectations, and not only on the expectation.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: Participants will not be informed about the deception that will be used and they will be informed about the real purpose and goal of the research after completing it.

question.value: Between subjects design with 3 factors (groups) and 2 levels (2 measurement points of dependent variables)

q7.value: After completing the training, participants will answer the anticipated questionnaires prepared in a paper-pen format. Participants will then be measured for baseline measures of dependent variables (speed and force of reaction and the subjective estimate of the intensity and discomfort of experienced pain). Based on those results (reaction time and force of reaction, questionnaire measures), participants will be divided into three equal independent groups using blocking randomization, that will differ based on the type of the placebo effect manipulation: a) the first experimental group which’s expectations of the effectiveness of the gel will only be simulated by the guidance, b) the second experimental group which’s expectations will also be induced by the same guidelines as in the first group case, but will also have an additional manipulation and covert reduction of the intensity of the stimuli which will ensure learning about the gel effectiveness (pairing the poor stimuli and the presence of the cream), c) control group which will have no treatment.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Participants will be young and healthy people aged 18 to 40 which will be recruited through social networks, invitation posters which will be placed near dormitories and through referrals. All participants of the research have to be naive about the purpose of the research so the possibility of their suspect towards a placebo manipulation should be minimized. All participants with neurological, cardiovascular or circulatory problems will be excluded from the study, as well as pregnant women and participants using medicine which could interfere with the research.
	All participants will need to attend the measurement in two separate terms and will be aware of the fact that they can end the examination process at any time. Scores on individual tests will be coded to preserve the confidentiality of participants and to pair results on different tests and measures. Participants will not be informed about the deception that will be used and they will be informed about the real purpose and goal of the research after completing it. At that moment they will have an opportunity to withdraw their research results and it will also be checked if participants doubted the deception and if they understood the experiment. Upon initial testing, all participants will sign an informed consent and complete an initial health status test.
After completing the second measurement, all participants will be appropriately rewarded for participation with prize money in the value of 50 HRK or awards valued 50 HRK. The duration of testing during the first visit is up to 30 minutes and during the second visit up to 45 minutes. The time delay between the first and the second testing will be 7 to 10 days and both tests will be conducted approximately at the same time of the day. Two weeks after the second testing participants will be invited to complete Pain Sensitivity Questionnaire once again to check the test-retest reliability of the translated version. Next, they will be informed about the main purpose of the study.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 12 participants per group (three groups). We will attempt to recruit up to 70 participants, assuming that not all participants will come to the second measurement.

q12.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .90 power to detect an effect size based on Vase et al. (2002) meta-analyses, at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
Groups will differ on the way of placebo effect manipulation. The control group will have no manipulations nor will receive any placebo treatment. The first experimental group in the first part of testing (96 stimuli) will have placebo gel applied with the instruction that it is an effective newly developed analgesic whose effectiveness is being tested. They will be told that it was developed primarily for situations when the effect of the analgesic has to be relatively fast. The goal of the verbal guidance about effective analgesia is to induce analgesic expectations in a relatively short period after the gel application. In the second part of testing (96 stimuli) the same measurement will be repeated. Those results will be a measurement to compare with other groups regarding the estimate of the intensity of the placebo effect caused by expectations.
In the second experimental group, in the first part of testing participants will also have a placebo gel applied, but the intensity of stimulation will be covertly reduced (they will not know that they are receiving weaker stimuli) with the same instruction that the first experimental group received. In that way participants will pair, alongside their general expectations caused by the instruction, the presence of a placebo gel and weaker experience (caused by weaker stimuli), meaning that they will notice its effectiveness. In the second part of testing (96 stimuli) the intensity of stimulation will be normal again (not reduced) as in the first experimental group case. Measures of dependent variables from second measurement will present a baseline for comparison with other groups and a fundament to making a conclusion about the appearance and intensity of a placebo effect caused by expectations and paired stimulation.

Dependent variables: speed and force of simple motor reaction (a device connected to a computer and a stimulus device will be used for measuring speed and force of reaction) and subjective estimates of pain intensity (on a scale ranging from 1 (the weakest) to 30 (the strongest)) and discomfort caused by pain stimuli (on a scale ranging from 0 (no discomfort) to 10 (extremely unpleasant)). 
Independent variables: placebo manipulation (expectation only versus conditioning + expectation). 
To gather data on individual differences relevant to the subject of the measurement, the following questionnaires will be used: Pain Sensitivity Questionnaire (Ruscheweyh et al. 2009), Pain Catastrophizing Questionnaire (Sullivan et al. 1995), IPIP 50 Personality Questionnaire (Mlačić and Goldberg 2007), - emotional stability factor, STAI – state-trait anxiety inventory (Spielberger 1968), Sociodemographic Characteristics and Health Status Questionnaire: data on gender, age, occupational and educational status, chronic illnesses, and frequency of analgesic use.

To validate the translated form of Pain sensitivity scale, we will use the Pearson correlation, exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis as well as regression analyses. 
To test our hypothesis we will use 2 x 3 mixed-design ANOVA with posthoc tests or one-way ANOVA.

q20.value: Outliners for speed of reaction: <100ms and >450ms

q22.value:
We expect that demographic traits, as well as analgesic use and individual characteristics, may be related to placebo effect manifestation in both experimental groups.
We will validate the translated version on the Croatian language of Pain Sensitivity Questionnaire.

attributes.title: Healthy Talk
attributes.description: Field experiment: Using messaging to increase interpersonal communication and physical activity

q1.value: Healthy Talk: Interpersonal Communication and Physical Activity

q3.value:
This pre-registration concerns correlational and longitudinal analyses of the data collected in this project, controlling for condition.

RQ1: What is the relationship between physical activity behavior and the occurrence and valence of interpersonal communication about physical activity? 

RQ2: Who engages in interpersonal communication about physical activity? Are there individual differences that affect the valence of interpersonal communication about physical activity?

RQ3: What is the relationship between occurrence and valence of interpersonal communication on implicit attitudes and approach tendencies related to physical activity?

q4.value:
RQ1 Hypotheses:

H1: The occurrence of daily interpersonal communication about physical activity will be positively associated with the amount of physical activity on (H1a) the same day, and (H1b) the following day.

H2: More positively (H2a) and less negatively (H2b) valenced daily interpersonal communication about physical activity will be positively associated with the amount of physical activity on the same  day and the following day.

RQ2 Hypotheses:
Given the lack of prior evidence about individual difference effects on interpersonal communication, we will explore the effects of gender, age, SES, and motivations to engage in physical activity on occurrence and valence of interpersonal communication.

RQ3 Hypotheses:
H3: More frequent and, on average, more positive and less negative interpersonal communication during the field period will be positively associated with more positive implicit associations (H3a) with and stronger approach tendencies (H3b) towards physical activity.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Details are described on the Wiki for this project. The analyses described here concern cross-sectional and longitudinal associations between various key variables, controlling for experimental conditions. Specifically, the analyses utilize the following pieces of data:
- self-report data about individual differences measured at T1
- self-reported daily mobile diaries collected during the baseline and intervention periods
- daily FitBit data about step-count and activity intensity during the baseline and intervention periods
- T2 results of the Approach Avoidance Task (AAT) and single-category Implicit Association Test (SC-IAT)

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: At the time of pre-registration, 53 participants have completed the protocol. Descriptive statistics (means and correlations) have been computed for self-report data collected during the baseline period, specifically data on behavioral determinants (social norms, attitudes, self-efficacy, intentions). This is necessary to implement the tailoring manipulation. In addition, baseline and intervention period compliance scores for daily diary measures and FitBit data have been computed in order to determine participant reimbursement. No other analyses or data inspection steps have been conducted by any research team member.

question.value:
Inclusion criteria (determined during online screening; T0):
Participants are eligible for this study if their T0 self-reports fulfill the following criteria:
- Age > 17
- Speaks, writes, and understands English fluently
- Smartphone owner
- Answers "probably yes" or "definitely yes" to the question: "Thinking about the amount of physical activity you have done over the last month. Would you like to increase your current physical activity level in the near future?"
- Answers less than 7 to the question: "Think about your physical activity over the last month. On average, on how many days per week did you engage in at least 30 minutes of at least 'moderate' physical activity? Note: Moderate physical activity will increase your heart rate and make you breath harder. "

q13.value: We plan to recruit 90 participants for this study (30 per between-subject group). A number of variables are measured repeatedly for each person. Specifically, mobile daily diary measures (total of 21 assessments per person) include: occurrence and valence of interpersonal communication about physical activity, self-reported physical activity, and objectively logged physical activity.

q14.value: Sample size is constrained by the availability of seed funding and personnel.

question.value: Manipulated variables in this project include the message engagement (between-subject) and tailoring (within-subject) interventions. These are fully described in the wiki for this project. For the current pre-registration, these variables are entered in the analyses as dummy control variables.

Conversational occurrence and valence are measured once per day during the baseline and intervention periods at 8 PM using daily mobile diaries sent to participants mobile phones:

- Occurrence of interpersonal communication about physical activity: "During the last 24 hours, have you talked to anyone (in person or through some medium) about physical activity?" [Yes/No]
- If Occurrence is answered with "Yes", participants are also asked about conversational valence: "On average, during the last 24 hours, to what extent were your interactions about physical activity.." 1) positive about engaging in physical activity [1: not at all-5: very much]; 2) negative about engaging in physical activity [1: not at all-5: very much]

Physical Activity Behavior
Physical activity is measured daily during the baseline and intervention periods using FitBit Charge 3 devices. We operationalize physical activity in two ways:
1) daily step count and 
2) minutes spent in "fairly active" or "very active" activity as categorized by the FitBit app (https://help.fitbit.com/articles/en_US/Help_article/1379)

Individual difference measures are assessed through a questionnaire at T1:
- Gender "What is your gender? [Male/Female/Non-Binary]
- Age "How old are you? [open answer field]
- Motivations to engage in physical activity: Assessed using the PALMS questionnaire https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4168060/

At T2, participants complete a single-category implicit association test and an approach avoidance task for physical activity implemented in PsychoPy. Both tasks are available and described in detail in the Wiki.

The PALMS is scored as 8 separate sub-scales (i.e. the sum of ratings on each item belonging to the sub-scales mastery, enjoyment, psychological condition, physical condition, appearance, other’s expectations, affiliation, and competition/ego.  In addition, we will examine an overall PALMS score that equals the sum of all item-wise ratings (see procedures in https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4168060/).

The AAT will be scored in accordance with procedures described in Cheval et al. (2018). Specifically, trials with response times below 150ms and above 1500 ms will be excluded from analysis. We will then calculate relative reaction times to approach (or avoid) stimuli showing sedentary and physical activity behaviors, respectively by subtracting the median reaction time of the participant when approaching (or avoiding) neutral stimuli from each reaction time when approaching (or avoiding) stimuli sedentary or physical activity behaviors, respectively. 

Before scoring the SC-IAT, we will exclude participants with an error rate greater than 20% from the analyses involving this task. Further, all practice trials as well as trials with response times faster than 150 ms and all error trials will be excluded from analysis. In accordance with Karpinski and Steinman (2006), we will use a D-score algorithm to score the task: Average response times for the "Physical Activity + Good"-block will be subtracted from the average response times of the "Physical Activity + Bad"-block. This difference score will be divided by the standard deviation of all correct response times within the "Physical Activity + Good" and "Physical Activity + Bad" blocks.

>>>H1: The occurrence of daily interpersonal communication (IC_occ) about physical activity (PA) will be positively associated with the amount of physical activity on (H1a) the same day, and (H1b) the following day.

H1 will be tested using multi-level regression models in R ('LmerTest') controlling for dummy-coded experimental between (bw_cond) and within subject conditions (w_cond) as well as time (represented as # of days since T1; Day) and allowing for varying intercepts across participants (pID).

lmer(PA~IC_occ+bw_cond+w_cond+time+(1|pID),data=df), where separate models will be estimated for different PA indicators as well as for same day and previous day IC (i.e. 4 models).

In addition, we will test the extent to which these effects are time-sensitive as opposed to general average associations between these variables by including normal levels of physical activity (IPAQ measured at T1) and self-reported interpersonal communication at T1 (IC_freq) for each participant into the model. 

lmer(PA~IC+bw_cond+w_cond+IC_freq+T1_IPAQ+(1|pID)+(1|Day),data=df).


>>>H2: More positively (H2a) and less negatively (H2b) valenced daily interpersonal communication about physical activity will be positively associated with the amount of physical activity on the same  day and the following day.

H2 will be tested using multi-level regression models in R ('LmerTest') controlling for dummy-coded experimental between (bw_cond) and within subject conditions (w_cond) as well as time (represented as # of days since T1; Day) and allowing for varying intercepts across participants (pID).

lmer(PA~IC_val_pos+bw_cond+w_cond+time+(1|pID),data=df), where separate models will be estimated for different PA indicators as well as for same day and previous day IC (i.e. 4 models).

lmer(PA~IC_val_neg+bw_cond+w_cond+time+(1|pID),data=df), where separate models will be estimated for different PA indicators as well as for same day and previous day IC (i.e. 4 models).

In addition, we will test the extent to which these effects are time-sensitive as opposed to general average associations between these variables by including normal levels of physical activity (IPAQ measured at T1) and self-reported interpersonal communication at T1 (IC_freq) for each participant into the model.

lmer(PA~IC_val_pos+bw_cond+w_cond+IC_freq+T1_IPAQ+(1|pID)+(1|Day),data=df).
lmer(PA~IC_val_neg+bw_cond+w_cond+IC_freq+T1_IPAQ+(1|pID)+(1|Day),data=df).

>>>RQ2 Hypotheses:
Given the lack of prior evidence about individual difference effects on interpersonal communication, we will explore the effects of gender, age, SES, and motivations to engage in physical activity on occurrence and valence of interpersonal communication.

We will explore this RQ using linear regression models in R controlling for dummy-coded experimental between (bw_cond) and within subject conditions (w_cond). Before analysis, repeated measures data will be aggregated per person as follows:
- Interpersonal communication occurrence will be computed as the percentage of the total number of days on which reports are available for a given person on which interpersonal communication about physical activity occured.
- Positive and negative valence of interpersonal communication about physical activity will be averaged for each person.

lm(IC_occ~gender+age+SES+motivations+bw_cond+w_cond+time,data=df).
lm(IC_val_pos~gender+age+SES+motivations+bw_cond+w_cond+time,data=df).
lm(IC_val_neg~gender+age+SES+motivations+bw_cond+w_cond+time,data=df).

RQ3 Hypotheses:
H3: More frequent and, on average, more positive and less negative interpersonal communication during the field period will be positively associated with more positive implicit associations (H3a; IAT) and with stronger approach tendencies (H3b) towards physical activity (AAT).

To test this hypothesis, we will use person-level aggregated measures of interpersonal communication occurrence and valence as described in the analysis plan for H2. We will use linear regression models to test H3 controlling for dummy-coded experimental between (bw_cond) and within subject conditions (w_cond).

lmer(IAT~IC_occ+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df)
lmer(IAT~IC_val_neg+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df)
lmer(IAT~IC_val_pos+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df)

lmer(AAT~IC_occ+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df)
lmer(AAT~IC_val_neg+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df)
lmer(AAT~IC_val_pos+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df

q20.value: For all models, non-dichotomous variables will be grant-mean centered before analysis. Variables that violate normality assumptions will be transformed.

q21.value: P-values of less than 0.05 will be considered "significant" for the purpose of this study.

q23.value: Missing data will be excluded from analysis and not imputed.

- If Occurrence is answered with "Yes", participants are also asked about conversational valence: "On average, during the last 24 hours, to what extent were your interactions about physical activity.." 1) positive about engaging in physical activity [1: not at all-5: very much]; 2) negative about engaging in physical activity [1: not at all-5: very much]

Physical Activity Behavior
Physical activity is measured daily during the baseline and intervention periods using FitBit Charge 3 devices. We operationalize physical activity in two ways:
1) daily step count and 
2) minutes spent in "fairly active" or "very active" activity as categorized by the FitBit app (https://help.fitbit.com/articles/en_US/Help_article/1379)

Individual difference measures are assessed through a questionnaire at T1:
- Gender "What is your gender? [Male/Female/Non-Binary]
- Age "How old are you? [open answer field]
- Motivations to engage in physical activity: Assessed using the PALMS questionnaire https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4168060/

At T2, participants complete a single-category implicit association test and an approach avoidance task for physical activity implemented in PsychoPy. Both tasks are available and described in detail in the Wiki.
registration_responses.q18.question:
The PALMS is scored as 8 separate sub-scales (i.e. the sum of ratings on each item belonging to the sub-scales mastery, enjoyment, psychological condition, physical condition, appearance, other’s expectations, affiliation, and competition/ego.  In addition, we will examine an overall PALMS score that equals the sum of all item-wise ratings (see procedures in https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4168060/).

The AAT will be scored in accordance with procedures described in Cheval et al. (2018). Specifically, trials with response times below 150ms and above 1500 ms will be excluded from analysis. We will then calculate relative reaction times to approach (or avoid) stimuli showing sedentary and physical activity behaviors, respectively by subtracting the median reaction time of the participant when approaching (or avoiding) neutral stimuli from each reaction time when approaching (or avoiding) stimuli sedentary or physical activity behaviors, respectively. 

Before scoring the SC-IAT, we will exclude participants with an error rate greater than 20% from the analyses involving this task. Further, all practice trials as well as trials with response times faster than 150 ms and all error trials will be excluded from analysis. In accordance with Karpinski and Steinman (2006), we will use a D-score algorithm to score the task: Average response times for the "Physical Activity + Good"-block will be subtracted from the average response times of the "Physical Activity + Bad"-block. This difference score will be divided by the standard deviation of all correct response times within the "Physical Activity + Good" and "Physical Activity + Bad" blocks.
registration_responses.q19.question:
>>>H1: The occurrence of daily interpersonal communication (IC_occ) about physical activity (PA) will be positively associated with the amount of physical activity on (H1a) the same day, and (H1b) the following day.

H1 will be tested using multi-level regression models in R ('LmerTest') controlling for dummy-coded experimental between (bw_cond) and within subject conditions (w_cond) as well as time (represented as # of days since T1; Day) and allowing for varying intercepts across participants (pID).

lmer(PA~IC_occ+bw_cond+w_cond+time+(1|pID),data=df), where separate models will be estimated for different PA indicators as well as for same day and previous day IC (i.e. 4 models).

In addition, we will test the extent to which these effects are time-sensitive as opposed to general average associations between these variables by including normal levels of physical activity (IPAQ measured at T1) and self-reported interpersonal communication at T1 (IC_freq) for each participant into the model. 

lmer(PA~IC+bw_cond+w_cond+IC_freq+T1_IPAQ+(1|pID)+(1|Day),data=df).


>>>H2: More positively (H2a) and less negatively (H2b) valenced daily interpersonal communication about physical activity will be positively associated with the amount of physical activity on the same  day and the following day.

H2 will be tested using multi-level regression models in R ('LmerTest') controlling for dummy-coded experimental between (bw_cond) and within subject conditions (w_cond) as well as time (represented as # of days since T1; Day) and allowing for varying intercepts across participants (pID).

lmer(PA~IC_val_pos+bw_cond+w_cond+time+(1|pID),data=df), where separate models will be estimated for different PA indicators as well as for same day and previous day IC (i.e. 4 models).

lmer(PA~IC_val_neg+bw_cond+w_cond+time+(1|pID),data=df), where separate models will be estimated for different PA indicators as well as for same day and previous day IC (i.e. 4 models).

In addition, we will test the extent to which these effects are time-sensitive as opposed to general average associations between these variables by including normal levels of physical activity (IPAQ measured at T1) and self-reported interpersonal communication at T1 (IC_freq) for each participant into the model.

lmer(PA~IC_val_pos+bw_cond+w_cond+IC_freq+T1_IPAQ+(1|pID)+(1|Day),data=df).
lmer(PA~IC_val_neg+bw_cond+w_cond+IC_freq+T1_IPAQ+(1|pID)+(1|Day),data=df).

>>>RQ2 Hypotheses:
Given the lack of prior evidence about individual difference effects on interpersonal communication, we will explore the effects of gender, age, SES, and motivations to engage in physical activity on occurrence and valence of interpersonal communication.

We will explore this RQ using linear regression models in R controlling for dummy-coded experimental between (bw_cond) and within subject conditions (w_cond). Before analysis, repeated measures data will be aggregated per person as follows:
- Interpersonal communication occurrence will be computed as the percentage of the total number of days on which reports are available for a given person on which interpersonal communication about physical activity occured.
- Positive and negative valence of interpersonal communication about physical activity will be averaged for each person.

lm(IC_occ~gender+age+SES+motivations+bw_cond+w_cond+time,data=df).
lm(IC_val_pos~gender+age+SES+motivations+bw_cond+w_cond+time,data=df).
lm(IC_val_neg~gender+age+SES+motivations+bw_cond+w_cond+time,data=df).

RQ3 Hypotheses:
H3: More frequent and, on average, more positive and less negative interpersonal communication during the field period will be positively associated with more positive implicit associations (H3a; IAT) and with stronger approach tendencies (H3b) towards physical activity (AAT).

To test this hypothesis, we will use person-level aggregated measures of interpersonal communication occurrence and valence as described in the analysis plan for H2. We will use linear regression models to test H3 controlling for dummy-coded experimental between (bw_cond) and within subject conditions (w_cond).

lmer(IAT~IC_occ+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df)
lmer(IAT~IC_val_neg+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df)
lmer(IAT~IC_val_pos+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df)

lmer(AAT~IC_occ+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df)
lmer(AAT~IC_val_neg+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df)
lmer(AAT~IC_val_pos+bw_cond+w_cond,data=df

attributes.title: Moral Persuasion
attributes.description: This is a pilot study to test whether arguments related to harm or liberty evoke concerns related to the harm or liberty moral foundations respectively.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Testing materials for study: Moral reframing and attitude change towards big data technologies

sample.value: For a model with four between-subject conditions and six repeated measures (six foundation questions), we calculate a total sample size of 168. This is based on a medium effect size of f = 0.25, alpha of 0.05 to reach 95% power. Keeping the effect size, alpha, and power the same, for a model with four between-subject conditions and two repeated measures (moral/practical concerns or emotional/rational arguments), we calculate a total sample size of 212. In order to have stable effects, we aim for at least 75 participants per condition or a total of 300 participants. We add ten extra participants to account for dropout.

analyses.value:
1. To test the first and second hypothesis, we will use a multilevel model with the response on the foundations (questions 1 to 6) as the dependent variable, an interaction between condition (harm, liberty, non-moral, and control) and foundation (concerns of harm, unfairness, impurity, disloyalty, obedience, and restrictions on liberty) as a fixed factor, and participant ID as a random factor.
2. To test the third hypothesis, we will use a multilevel model with the response on moral/practical concerns (questions 7 and 8) as the dependent variable, an interaction between condition (harm, liberty, non-moral, and control) and type of concern (moral or practical) as a fixed factor, and participant ID as a random factor.
3. To test the fourth hypothesis, we will use a multilevel model with the response on emotional/rational arguments (questions 9 and 10) as the dependent variable, an interaction between condition (harm, liberty, non-moral, and control) and type of argument (rational or emotional) as a fixed factor, and participant ID as a random factor.

outliers.value: Analyses will include all participants with available data (i.e. a pair-wise deletion strategy).

dependent.value:
1.	To what extent are the author’s arguments based in concerns of harm? (1 = not at all; 7 = very much)
2.	To what extent are the author’s arguments based in concerns of unfairness? 1 = not at all; 7 = very much)
3.	To what extent are the author’s arguments based in concerns of impurity? 1 = not at all; 7 = very much)
4.	To what extent are the author’s arguments based in concerns of disloyalty? 1 = not at all; 7 = very much)
5.	To what extent are the author’s arguments based in concerns of disobedience? 1 = not at all; 7 = very much)
6.	To what extent are the author’s arguments based in concerns of restrictions on liberty? 1 = not at all; 7 = very much)
7.	To what extent are the author’s arguments related to moral concerns? (1 = not at all; 7 = very much)
8.	To what extent are the author’s arguments related to practical concerns? (1 = not at all; 7 = very much)
9.	To what extent are the author’s arguments emotional? (1 = not at all; 7 = very much)
10.	To what extent are the author’s arguments rational? (1 = not at all; 7 = very much)
11.	How strong are the author’s arguments? (1 = not strong at all; 7 = extremely strong)
12.	To what extent does the author oppose or support the technology? (1  = strongly oppose; 4 = neither oppose nor support; 7 = strongly support)

conditions.value: Participants will be assigned to one of four conditions. They either see a harm-related message, a liberty-related message, a non-moral message, or a control message.

hypothesis.value:
This is a pilot study. We present participants with persuasive messages that oppose a new technology that could help solve crimes. These messages use arguments either based in harm, liberty, non-moral concerns, or a neutral description. We are interested in whether or not these messages are perceived how we intend.

1.	We predict that participants who read the harm-related message score higher in the extent to which they see the author’s arguments as based in harm compared to participants who read the other three messages. In this condition, participants also score higher for the harm scores compared to scores on concerns of unfairness, impurity, disloyalty, disobedience, or restrictions on liberty.
2.	We predict that participants who read the liberty-related message score higher in the extent to which they see the author’s arguments as based in restrictions on liberty compared to participants who read the other three messages. In this condition, participants also score higher for the liberty scores compared to concerns of harm, unfairness, impurity, disloyalty, or disobedience.
3.	We predict that the non-moral message is rated higher for its relation to practical concerns compared to the other three messages while the harm and liberty-related messages are rated higher for their relation to moral concerns compared to the non-moral and control message.
4.	We predict that the arguments in the non-moral message are rated as more rational compared to the other three messages while arguments in the harm and liberty-related messages are rated as more emotional compared to the non-moral and control message.

attributes.title: What mobilizes us more, gender equality or climate emergency? Social engagement, Zeitgeist, and social norms
attributes.description:
The study will explore social engagement with two socially relevant causes, gender-equality and climate protection. The rationale for this comparative analysis is that, in spite of high importance of both issues for the society as a whole, there are observable differences in the extent to which they have mobilizing potential among the citizens. Thus, while gender-related social agenda have become powerful determinate of social and political practices and discourse, climate protection problem, although it is becoming more and more recognized as urgent and of extreme importance, is still addressed less by social and political actors. Therefore, the main goal of the study is to compare the levels of social engagement with each issue among the citizens, and also to examine the relative power of several predictors. Namely, we will analyse the role of social norms, the sense of moral obligation, self-identity, and past behaviour for social engagement. Additionally, we will explore whether the perceived salience of the issue in the society (which we call “zeitgeist”) will differ for the issues studied, and whether this perceived relevance will influence engagement.  
The research will be conducted among university students. It will focus on two sources of social norms among them. We will research whether perceived norms for gender equality social engagement are higher than norms perceived for the engagement with climate protection. This would reflect the normative pressure existing for each issue. In order to account for diverse sources of social influence, we will focus on two types of these sources. On the one hand, we will study descriptive and injunctive norms coming from the reference group. On the other hand, in order to analyse the role of the more immediate context, we will explore the role of perceived descriptive and injunctive norms existing at the university campus. In this context, we will also test whether the degree to which the campus represents the source of the reference group will moderate the impact of campus social norms on engagement. 
We will also study moral obligation and self-identity as determinants of engagement. Moral obligation and self-identity are established predictors of behaviour, and we expect them to predict social engagement in our study. Besides, and adopting the social interactionist perspective, we will test the idea that social interactions and social context, reflected in the measures of social norms, shape individual sense of moral obligation. Therefore, we will test our hypothesis that norms impact engagement directly, and also indirectly, via increased moral obligation to mobilize for the issue, and also via strengthened self-identity as an advocate for the cause.  
Finally, we will include past behaviour as the predictor of engagement. 
In addition, we will try to apply Jackson's (1975) return potential model (RPM) to quantify the social context in which normative forces are at work. This measurement of the normative environment includes capturing both the extremity and consensus associated with expressed opinions. We will calculate these two measures as applied to both, the reference group´s norms and the norms perceived at the campus. The “intensity” of a norm quantifies the degree of approval or disapproval for an opinion or a behavior. As described in Glynn, Huge, & Lunney (2009), intensity is calculated by taking the deviation of each participant's score from the point of indifference (in our case, 3). Crystallization is calculated by taking the square root of the inverse of each respondent's absolute deviation from the mean approval rating among all respondents. Thus, crystallization of variable x for participant i is the square root of [1/(│x i−x mean│)]. Finally, the normative power is calculated by multiplying the normative intensity by crystallization.
The study has theoretical and applied interest. Regarding to its contribution to the theory, it will provide evidence on the relative and comparative impact of the variables that shape and predict social engagement. As regards its applied value, it will provide insights about the more effective way of promoting social engagement depending on the characteristics of the cause.


Jackson, J. M. 1975. Normative power and conflict potential. Sociological Methods and Research, 4, 237–263.
Glynn, C. J., Huge, M. E., & Lunney, C. A. (2009). The influence of perceived social norms on college students' intention to vote. Political Communication, 26(1), 48-64

q2.value:
Social engagement will be higher for gender-equality cause as compared to climate protection cause.
The perceived salience of the issue (Zeitgeist) in the society will be higher for gender-equality issue as compared to climate protection issue.
Perceived social norms (both descriptive and injunctive, and with respect to the reference group and to the university group) will be higher for gender-equality cause.
Past participation in mobilizations will predict actual engagement and behavioural intention to mobilize in the future.
There will be differences in which social norms predict engagement in the case of gender-equality related and climate-protection directed social participation. 
Moral obligation predicts social engagement.
Self-identity predicts social engagement. 
Social norms will predict engagement, and this relationship will be mediated by moral obligation. 
Social norms will predict engagement, and this relationship will be mediated by self-identity.
The impact of university-based social norms will be moderated by the extent to which the university represents the source of the reference group.  
Moral obligation is predicted by social norms (injunctive), and self-identity.
Gender (being a woman) will be stronger related to gender-equality engagement.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Correlational design based on a survey conducted among university students.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through advertisements made by the researchers while visiting their classes at Somosaguas Campus of the Complutense University of Madrid. They will be assured the anonymity of their responses. An informed consent will be given to each voluntary participant to sign before completing a survey.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 146 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 300, assuming that not all will complete the total survey, and that there will be outliers.

q12.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
There will be identical measures for gender-equality, and climate-protection causes.
Social engagement will be measured in three manners: 1) past participation (1 item); 2) intention to participate in the future (1 item); 3) current participation (5 items). All measures will use 1 “never” – 5 “very often” scale.
The perceived salience of the issue will be measured with two items (“In the last 30 days an average person in the country has encountered with the issue”) on a scale 1 “never” – 5 “many times”. 
Social norms will be measured in the following manner: 
Reference group: descriptive (2 items, “Most people important to me participate in mobilizations for…”), injunctive (2 items, “Most people important to me would feel disappointed if I would not participate in mobilizations for…”). The scale ranges from 1 “very much disagree” to 5 “very much agree”).
University group norms will be measured by asking about the percentage of people at the campus who participate in the mobilizations for the cause (descriptive norm, 2 items) and expect a participant to do so (injunctive norm, 2 items). The response range will be from 0% to 100%.
Moral obligation scale will consist of 5 items (“To mobilize for… represents a moral obligation to oneself”, on a scale 1 “Very much disagree” to 5 “very much agree”).
Self-identity will be measured with 2 items (“Being an advocate for gender-equality is an important part of who I am”), with the response options ranging from 1 “not at all” to 5 “very much”.
The presence of the reference group at the university campus (1 item) will be measured with a pictorial scale consisting of two circles (“my people” and “people on the Campus”) overlapping to a different degree. There will be 5 options ranging from 1 representing no overlap to 5 representing a high degree of overlap.
Demographics will include questions about age, gender, and political ideology.
Engagement with the survey: the extent to which a participant took completing the survey seriously will be measured with one item with the response options ranging from 1 “not seriously at all” to 7 “very seriously”.
All the items for each scale will be combined to create a single measure.

We will apply the following analyses: 
1) mean comparisons (one-tailed t-test)
2) bivariate Pearson correlations 
3) multiple regressions
4) mediation and moderation analyses

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q20.value:
Due to the fact that senior citizens can also study at the university, and in order to ensure that all the participants of the study are at approximately the same developmental stage, age outliers will be excluded from the analysis.
Also, participants who fails to answer the question regarding their engagement with the survey or those who scores less than four will be excluded from the study.

q21.value: If a subject does not complete more than one third part of the survey, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q22.value: We expect that certain demographic traits (age, political ideology) may be related to social engagement and its correlates. Therefore, we will look for relationships between these variables and the primary measures of the study. We will also explore mutual relationships between all the variables.

attributes.title: The effect of hunger on the relationship between odor-taste congruence and pleasantness in healthy individuals
attributes.description: The aim of this study is to test if the effect of semantic congruency of odor-taste mixtures on pleasantness ratings is affected by whether the rater is hungry or satiated.

question2a.value:
1.	FLAVOR TYPICALITY, within subject variable. Continuous variable bounded at 0.01 and 1. Participants rated flavor typicality by using a visual analog scale (Figure 1, green tick marks and numbers are included to depict the associated score) with the endpoints Lemonade and Chicken broth. Whey were asked to click somewhere on the scale to describe what they thought the flavor tasted like. Ratings were converted in a linear fashion to a score between 0.01 and 1, where 1 indicated a click on one of the endpoints (Lemonade or Chicken broth) and 0.01 indicated a click on the tick mark in the middle that represented a perceptual 50/50.  
2.	STATE, within subject variable. Factor with two levels: hungry/full, indicating which testing session the rating had been obtained during.

question2b.value: 1.	PLEASANTNESS, within subject variable. Participants rated how much they liked the flavors by clicking on a visual analog scale with the endpoints Not at all and Very much. Ratings were converted in a linear fashion to a score between 0.01 and 1.00.

question10b.value:
Stimuli
The stimuli consisted of odorants and tastants dissolved in water and presented retronasally in 3 ml samples in medicine cups. The odorants were themselves mixtures of two target odors: chicken and lemon. Together, they formed a dilution series ranging from '100%chicken+0%lemon' to '0%chicken+100% lemon' in eleven 10%-steps with '50%chicken+50%lemon' in the middle. Each odorant was mixed twice, once with a sweet+sour taste solution and once with a salty+savory taste solution, producing a total of 22 stimuli. These odor-taste mixtures, or flavors, spanned the full spectrum from highly congruent (lemonade: '0%chicken+100% lemon' odor and sweet+sour taste, chicken broth: '100%chicken+0%lemon' odor and salty+savory taste) to highly incongruent mixtures ('100%chicken+0% lemon' odor and sweet+sour taste, '0%chicken+100%lemon' odor and salty+savory taste).  

Procedure 
Participant attended two testing sessions separated by approximately one week. These sessions were identical except that before the STATE:full-session, participants were served a standardized meal, while the STATE:hungry-session was completed on an empty stomach after a 6-hour fast. Every second participant started with the STATE:full-session and every second participant started with STATE:hungry-session. During both sessions, participants first completed one Training block with 6 trials, and then two Experiment blocks with 36 trials each. Psychopy was used throughout the experiment to present instructions on a computer screen, control the timing of the different steps in the trials, and log responses. For all trial in the Training block and Experiment block 1, participants were instructed to: 
1.	Taste the liquid in one of the cups
2.	Rate some aspect of the experience while having the liquid inside the mouth
3.	Expectorate the liquid 
4.	Rinse with water to clean the mouth
5.	Expectorate the rinsing water  
This structure was repeated in Experiment block 2, except that step 2 and 3 switched places so that ratings were collected after and not before expectoration. The presentation order of the stimuli was pseudo-randomized (<3 identical tastes in a row) and counterbalanced between participants to minimize order-effect.

Training block. The aim of this block was to establish a common perceptual representation of the target flavors. Participants were presented with six cups, two containing water, two containing the congruent lemonade flavor, and two containing the congruent chicken broth flavor. They were instructed to taste the cups one at a time and identify the flavor, choosing between “Water”, “Lemonade” and “Chicken broth”.  

Experiment block 1: Flavor typicality. Participants were then instructed to taste 36 cups one at a time and rate how similar each flavor was to lemonade/chicken broth by using the scale in Figure 1 (without the green tick marks and numbers). The 36 cups contained the 22 odor-taste mixtures, the 11 odorants at a concentration of 50%, the 2 tastants at a concentration of 50%, and plain water. Clicking on the scale logged the response and removed the image.

Experiment block 2: Pleasantness. After a short break, the same 36 cups were presented in the same order. But this time, participants were prompted to rate how much they liked the flavors. As before, clicking on the scale logged the response and removed the image.

H2.	Flavors will be rated as more pleasant when participants are hungry compared to when they are full

question2a.value: H4.	This effect of flavor typicality on pleasantness will be stronger when participants are hungry compared to when they are full

question3a.value:
Participants will attend two testing sessions, one that will be completed on an empty stomach after a 6-hour fast, and one where a standardized meal will be served prior to testing. Before both testing sessions, participants will provide hungriness ratings on a scale between 1 (not hungry at all) and 100 (extremely hungry). We expect ratings to be higher during the former than the latter session. 

To test this, a paired sample t-test will be used to compare hungriness ratings between the two testing sessions (STATE: hungry/full). We expect these ratings to by higher during STATE:hungry than during STATE:full.

question1c.value: All variables have already been described in the Methods-section.

question2c.value:
FLAVOR TYPICALITY (continuous variable bounded at 0.01 and 1) will be predicted using a linear mixed effects model (LMM) with STATE (factor with two levels: hungry/full) as the only fixed effect. We expect the fixed effect to be significant, and ratings to be higher for STATE:hungry than for STATE:full. 

For all analyses, p-values will be obtained by likelihood ratio tests comparing models with and without the effect of interest.

question4c.value: To account for repeated measures, random intercept by participant will be included in the analysis, together with random slopes for the fixed effect. If the model fails to converge, the by-subject random slope will be removed.

question2c.value:
The same model will then be used to assess the effect of FLAVOR TYPICALITY on PLEASANTNESS. We expect this effect to be positive and significant. 

But this time, if the model fails to converge, the by-subject random slope for STATE will be removed before the by-subject random slope for FLAVOR TYPICALITY.

question1c.value: FLAVOR TYPICALITY. As each participant rated each flavor twice, once per testing session, these two ratings will be merged so that each stimulus only gets one flavor typicality score per participant. This score will simply be the mean of the two ratings. The rest of the variables have already been described.

question2c.value: A third LMM will then be defined with FLAVOR TYPICALITY, STATE and their INTERACTION as predictors, and PLEASANTNESS as the dependent variable. We expect the INTERACTION to be significant, and the effect of FLAVOR TYPICALITY to be stronger for STATE:hungry than for STATE:full.

question4c.value: To account for repeated measures, random intercept by participant will be included in all the analyses, together with random slopes for the fixed effects. If a model fails to converge, the by-subject random slope(s) will be removed one at a time (first the interaction, then FLAVOR TYPICALITY, and then STATE).

attributes.title: scoping review: sinus tarsi syndrome - what do we know and does it really exist ?
attributes.description: Little is currently known about the aetiology, diagnosis and treatment of sinus tarsi syndrome. Some authors even argue that the term should not exist and instead be replaced with a more specific diagnoses. This scoping review aims to map the current literature pertaining to the aetiology, diagnosis and treatment of sinus tarsi  syndrome in order to help improve readers’ understanding of this condition and answer the question of whether the term should be used or not.

attributes.title: Database of virtual objects to be used in psychological research
attributes.description: Here we share 121 3D objects that have been developed for scientific purposes. Objects were built in Maya and then exported to fbx format and online rendered using Unreal Engine 4 application. Our goal was to develop a first set of high-quality virtual objects, standardized for name, familiarity, and visual complexity.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Database of virtual objects to be used in psychological research

other.value: For composite names, we will rearrange the words.

sample.value: N≈80. The specification of the sample size is mainly based on resource limitations. However, we do think that N≈80 will be sufficiently large to validate the database. We plan to to test 100 participants in order to achieve the aimed sample size of approximately 80 participants also after eventual exclusions.

analyses.value:
We will define the name of the virtual object by the name given by the highest number of participants. Moreover, we will compute percentage of agreement for individual objects.
We will compute central tendency (mean and median) for the ratings for individual objects (familiarity and complexity) and overall.

outliers.value:
1) Responses that cannot be linked to a submitted request for payment. 
2) Duplicate responses: only the first response associated with a workerID will be retained.
3) Responses from non US participants.

dependent.value: The name of the object and the ratings for familiarity and complexity rated on a 5-point Likert scale, see below for more details.

conditions.value:
The sample will be recruited from Amazon’s website Mechanical Turk. All participants will be first asked to report informed consent, and then they report age, gender, employment, country of residence, and country of origin. Moreover, they certify to be at least 18 years of age, and that they understand written English well. 

Then they will be presented with the 120 objects. For each object, they will be asked the following questions:

"Identify the object as briefly and unambiguously as possible by writing only one name, the first name that comes to your mind. The name can be composed of more than one word".

"Rate the level to which the image appears to be complex in terms of the quantity of details and the intricacy of the lines". (5-point Likert scale, ranging from not complex at all to very complex).

"Rate the level to which you are familiar with the object". (5-point Likert scale, ranging from not familiar at all to very familiar).

hypothesis.value:
Our goal is to develop a first set of 3D virtual objects to be used in Virtual Reality settings, standardized for name, familiarity, and visual complexity. 
Participants will be presented with 120 short videos of the objects. They will be asked to name the object and to evaluate the familiarity and complexity of the object.

attributes.title: The economic benefit of artificial intelligence-supported continuous vital signs monitoring systems in health care
attributes.description: Protocol for The economic evidence of artificial intelligence-supported continuous vital signs monitoring systems in health care: A scoping review

summary.value:
This protocol is based on the Joanna Briggs Institute's framework (see https://wiki.joannabriggs.org/display/MANUAL/Chapter+11%3A+Scoping+reviews)

TITLE
The economic evidence of artificial intelligence-supported continuous vital signs monitoring systems: A scoping review 

AUTHORS
Arendse Tange Larsen, Søren Rud Kristensen, Liza Sopina, Jakob Kjellberg, Eske Kvanner Aasvang, Helge Bjarup Dissing Sørensen, Christian Sylvest Meyhoff. 

MAIN RESEARCH QUESTION
What is the scope of the economic evidence of artificial-intelligence (AI) supported continuous vital signs monitoring (CVSM) systems and which (if any) special considerations does the use of AI technology imply for conducting economic analyses of such systems?

SUB-QUESTIONS
1.	What are the conclusions of the economic literature on AI-supported CVSM systems? 
2.	What are the methods being used for studying the economic evidence of AI-supported CVSM systems and (how) are they different from other economic analyses of CVSM systems?

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE
Monitoring of vital signs is a way to facilitate early detection of patient deterioration, thereby ensuring timely management of disease and prevention of adverse events (1–3). Manual approaches for monitoring vital signs are being widely used but are challenged by poor adherence to the scoring protocol, low detection rates and long time intervals between patient observations during which deterioration can occur undetected (1,4–6). Continuous monitoring designing a 24/7 clinical support system offers a potential solution to the inadequate monitoring frequency but the narrow window for medical intervention upon detection of deterioration, as well as false alarms, still constitute obstacles for improving outcomes (3,7). Therefore, an increasing interest for integrating artificial intelligence (AI) technologies to support continuous monitoring systems has recently evolved (3,7–11). 

AI is a rapidly growing field providing digital transformation of a broad range of businesses and industries, the health care sector being no exception. AI is increasingly being used or tested for different purposes in the health care sector. AI-supported health care technologies have in some cases proved comparable to human approaches by clinicians and some studies even point to increased accuracy of diagnosis and risk prediction (12,13). Additionally, the use of AI-supported health care technologies may improve chronic disease management, facilitate precision therapies for complex diseases, reduce medical errors etc. (14–16). Hence, the application of AI in healthcare is anticipated to change patient care and is associated with high expectations in terms of improved health outcomes, increased efficiency and reduced health care costs (12,13,17,18). However, the literature on how AI-supported health care technologies can and will meet these expectations is scarce.

The application of AI in patient monitoring enables the transformation of automatically and continuously measured vital signs into real-time predictive indicators of patients’ health status, which may facilitate proactive treatment of imminent deterioration (3,11). Hence, AI-supported continuous monitoring of vital signs building on automatic interpretation and classification of abnormal events is anticipated to reduce adverse events in the individual patient and improve general patient safety. Additionally, it allows for new workflows that may translate into more efficient processes and reduced health care costs. 

While the implementation and performance of some AI-supported CVSM systems have been examined (3,12,19–21), the question of the size and nature of the potential economic benefits of such systems remains unaddressed. 

Some economic aspects of CVSM systems and AI-supported health care technologies have been addressed each on their own in recent systematic reviews (1,18). Downey et al. (2018) examined the feasibility of using traditional CVSM systems outside the critical care setting and included both clinical and non-clinical outcomes, including a brief description of the cost-effectiveness of CVSM systems (1). The authors only identified three economic studies on CVSM systems. One study found an annual return of investment of 292.8 % and 92.5 % in the base case model and conservative model, respectively, mainly arising from decreased length of stay (22). Another study found that transfers to the intensive care unit (ICU) were not reduced but that the duration and costs of ICU stay were significantly less in patients monitored by the continuous monitoring system. However, the system did not reduce the overall costs of hospitalization (23). According to the authors, the reason for this might be that the monitoring was a short-lived component of a longer and complex hospitalization, which did not change the entire pathway and therefore did not reduce overall costs (23). A third study found that a continuous monitoring system was cost-effective in the initial year and that the cost-benefit increased significantly in the subsequent years (24). Based on these results, Downey et al. concluded that CVSM systems may be cost-effective (1). 

Wolff et al. (2020) published a systematic review to summarize published cost-effectiveness studies on the application of AI in health care in general and to assess whether current studies met five quality criteria formulated by the authors themselves, and derived from classical health care effectiveness studies and digital health assessments (18). The criteria comprised: Description of cost-effectiveness of AI solution; Hypothesis formulation; Cost-effectiveness perspective; Consideration of cost alternative; Benefit today; Verification of base case. 

The authors concluded that only few studies of AI in health care have been conducted and published; and that even fewer meet the authors’ quality criteria (18). The authors’ search strategy was not limited to any specific AI health care technologies but was, however, limited to only one database and few search terms for economic impact. None of the six AI health care technologies covered in the review comprised an AI-supported CVSM system.

Hence, while the health economics of traditional CVSM systems and general AI technologies in health care have been addressed in the literature, the health economic literature on AI-supported CVSM systems still remains to be studied. In this scoping review, we aim to do exactly so by exploring what the literature show and how the economic consequences of AI-supported CVSM systems have been investigated.

OVERALL OBJECTIVE
The overall objective of the scoping review is to acquire an overview of the health economic literature on AI-supported CVSM systems and to explore what characterizes economic analyses of such systems.

Hereby, we wish to i) understand the economic evidence of AI-supported CVSM systems, which can feed into the decision-making processes regarding implementation and operation of such systems, and ii) inform future research on how to conduct economic analyses of AI-supported CVSM systems.

We define AI-supported CVSM systems as systems with integration of AI technology to support automatic monitoring of one or more vital signs in patients at fixed time intervals. 

INCLUSION CRITERIA
- Types of participants: Hospitalized patients

- Concept: The conclusions and methods of health economic analyses of AI-supported CVSM systems. Outcomes of interest are not limited to monetary outcomes. Hence, outcomes such as resource use, length of stay, transfers to intensive care unit are also considered economic outcomes. Moreover, economic outcomes include socio-economic outcomes such as return to work and indirect costs.

- Context: The hospital sector, no country limits

- Types of studies: Any studies assessing the economic consequences of implementing an AI-supported CVSM system (cost-effectiveness studies, cost-utility studies, cost-benefit studies, budget impact analyses, return of investment analyses, costing analyses etc.). 

SEARCH STRATEGY
The search strategy will be divided into three parts as recommended by the Joanna Briggs Institute.

Step 1
Step 1 comprises an initial search in two databases (e.g. Medline and Academic Search Premier) and serves to provide inspiration for the subsequent search. In this step, relevant keywords and index terms will be identified in titles and abstracts of studies obtained from the search.

Step 2
In step 2 a comprehensive systematic literature search will be conducted using the following 11 electronic databases: Academic Search Premier; CINAHL; EconLit; Embase; MEDLINE; Pubmed; The Cochrane Library; SveMed+; The NHS Economic Evaluation Database; Web of Science; SciVerse Scopus.

Additionally, we will conduct a search for grey literature using sources such as Google Scholar, Open Grey and websites of relevant agencies or institutes (e.g. ISPOR, NICE, NHS UK, IHE).

The search strategy will not be limited to study design or publication date but will be limited to studies written in English, Danish, Swedish or Norwegian.

Step 3
Finally, reference lists in the included studies will be searched for additional studies.

Relevant search terms will be identified on the basis of the following facets and will comprise both keywords and index terms (e.g. MeSH terms):

Facet 1: Artificial intelligence
Facet 2: Continuous vital signs monitoring systems
Facet 3: Health economics

See attached appendix for search strategy for one database.

STUDY SELECTION
Search results will be imported to a reference management system. The screening process will be divided into two parts. In the first part (level 1 screening) studies will be selected based on title and abstract. In the second part (level 2 screening) studies will be selected based on full text examination. The study selection will be performed by two reviewers. Any disagreements will be solved by consensus.

DATA EXTRACTION
For included articles key information relevant to the research question will be conducted according to the following charting form:

-	Author
-	Year of publication
-	Origin
-	Aim/purpose
-	Population details (and sample size)
-	Study design/methods
-	Intervention details, including whether the AI technology is an add-on to an existing monitoring system
-	Type of AI technology 
-	Vital sign(s) measured
-	Setting (e.g. intensive care unit or operating room)
-	Target population
-	Outcomes and measurement
-	Data sources
-	Challenges encountered/limitations
-	Reference standard/comparison (if any)
-	Key findings and conclusion according to authors

PRESENTATION OF RESULTS
Results will be summarized as descriptive tables as well as presented as a narrative synthesis.

This protocol is based on the Joanna Briggs Institute's framework (see https://wiki.joannabriggs.org/display/MANUAL/Chapter+11%3A+Scoping+reviews)

TITLE
The economic evidence of artificial intelligence-supported continuous vital signs monitoring systems: A scoping review 

AUTHORS
Arendse Tange Larsen, Søren Rud Kristensen, Liza Sopina, Jakob Kjellberg, Eske Kvanner Aasvang, Helge Bjarup Dissing Sørensen, Christian Sylvest Meyhoff. 

MAIN RESEARCH QUESTION
What is the scope of the economic evidence of artificial-intelligence (AI) supported continuous vital signs monitoring (CVSM) systems and which (if any) special considerations does the use of AI technology imply for conducting economic analyses of such systems?

SUB-QUESTIONS
1.	What are the conclusions of the economic literature on AI-supported CVSM systems? 
2.	What are the methods being used for studying the economic evidence of AI-supported CVSM systems and (how) are they different from other economic analyses of CVSM systems?

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE
Monitoring of vital signs is a way to facilitate early detection of patient deterioration, thereby ensuring timely management of disease and prevention of adverse events (1–3). Manual approaches for monitoring vital signs are being widely used but are challenged by poor adherence to the scoring protocol, low detection rates and long time intervals between patient observations during which deterioration can occur undetected (1,4–6). Continuous monitoring designing a 24/7 clinical support system offers a potential solution to the inadequate monitoring frequency but the narrow window for medical intervention upon detection of deterioration, as well as false alarms, still constitute obstacles for improving outcomes (3,7). Therefore, an increasing interest for integrating artificial intelligence (AI) technologies to support continuous monitoring systems has recently evolved (3,7–11). 

AI is a rapidly growing field providing digital transformation of a broad range of businesses and industries, the health care sector being no exception. AI is increasingly being used or tested for different purposes in the health care sector. AI-supported health care technologies have in some cases proved comparable to human approaches by clinicians and some studies even point to increased accuracy of diagnosis and risk prediction (12,13). Additionally, the use of AI-supported health care technologies may improve chronic disease management, facilitate precision therapies for complex diseases, reduce medical errors etc. (14–16). Hence, the application of AI in healthcare is anticipated to change patient care and is associated with high expectations in terms of improved health outcomes, increased efficiency and reduced health care costs (12,13,17,18). However, the literature on how AI-supported health care technologies can and will meet these expectations is scarce.

The application of AI in patient monitoring enables the transformation of automatically and continuously measured vital signs into real-time predictive indicators of patients’ health status, which may facilitate proactive treatment of imminent deterioration (3,11). Hence, AI-supported continuous monitoring of vital signs building on automatic interpretation and classification of abnormal events is anticipated to reduce adverse events in the individual patient and improve general patient safety. Additionally, it allows for new workflows that may translate into more efficient processes and reduced health care costs. 

While the implementation and performance of some AI-supported CVSM systems have been examined (3,12,19–21), the question of the size and nature of the potential economic benefits of such systems remains unaddressed. 

Some economic aspects of CVSM systems and AI-supported health care technologies have been addressed each on their own in recent systematic reviews (1,18). Downey et al. (2018) examined the feasibility of using traditional CVSM systems outside the critical care setting and included both clinical and non-clinical outcomes, including a brief description of the cost-effectiveness of CVSM systems (1). The authors only identified three economic studies on CVSM systems. One study found an annual return of investment of 292.8 % and 92.5 % in the base case model and conservative model, respectively, mainly arising from decreased length of stay (22). Another study found that transfers to the intensive care unit (ICU) were not reduced but that the duration and costs of ICU stay were significantly less in patients monitored by the continuous monitoring system. However, the system did not reduce the overall costs of hospitalization (23). According to the authors, the reason for this might be that the monitoring was a short-lived component of a longer and complex hospitalization, which did not change the entire pathway and therefore did not reduce overall costs (23). A third study found that a continuous monitoring system was cost-effective in the initial year and that the cost-benefit increased significantly in the subsequent years (24). Based on these results, Downey et al. concluded that CVSM systems may be cost-effective (1). 

Wolff et al. (2020) published a systematic review to summarize published cost-effectiveness studies on the application of AI in health care in general and to assess whether current studies met five quality criteria formulated by the authors themselves, and derived from classical health care effectiveness studies and digital health assessments (18). The criteria comprised: Description of cost-effectiveness of AI solution; Hypothesis formulation; Cost-effectiveness perspective; Consideration of cost alternative; Benefit today; Verification of base case. 

The authors concluded that only few studies of AI in health care have been conducted and published; and that even fewer meet the authors’ quality criteria (18). The authors’ search strategy was not limited to any specific AI health care technologies but was, however, limited to only one database and few search terms for economic impact. None of the six AI health care technologies covered in the review comprised an AI-supported CVSM system.

Hence, while the health economics of traditional CVSM systems and general AI technologies in health care have been addressed in the literature, the health economic literature on AI-supported CVSM systems still remains to be studied. In this scoping review, we aim to do exactly so by exploring what the literature show and how the economic consequences of AI-supported CVSM systems have been investigated.

OVERALL OBJECTIVE
The overall objective of the scoping review is to acquire an overview of the health economic literature on AI-supported CVSM systems and to explore what characterizes economic analyses of such systems.

Hereby, we wish to i) understand the economic evidence of AI-supported CVSM systems, which can feed into the decision-making processes regarding implementation and operation of such systems, and ii) inform future research on how to conduct economic analyses of AI-supported CVSM systems.

We define AI-supported CVSM systems as systems with integration of AI technology to support automatic monitoring of one or more vital signs in patients at fixed time intervals. 

INCLUSION CRITERIA
- Types of participants: Hospitalized patients

- Concept: The conclusions and methods of health economic analyses of AI-supported CVSM systems. Outcomes of interest are not limited to monetary outcomes. Hence, outcomes such as resource use, length of stay, transfers to intensive care unit are also considered economic outcomes. Moreover, economic outcomes include socio-economic outcomes such as return to work and indirect costs.

- Context: The hospital sector, no country limits

- Types of studies: Any studies assessing the economic consequences of implementing an AI-supported CVSM system (cost-effectiveness studies, cost-utility studies, cost-benefit studies, budget impact analyses, return of investment analyses, costing analyses etc.).
